<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 276, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
0625/63  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 326, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 6 Alternative to Practical  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 300, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
May/June 2021  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[853, 325, 905, 340]]<|/det|>
1 hour  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 395, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 560]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 603]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 636]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 702, 91]]<|/det|>
The student measures the length \(l_{0}\) of the spring without any load.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[571, 98, 920, 122]]<|/det|>
\[l_{0} = ............................................2.3 \quad \text{cm}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 133, 801, 152]]<|/det|>
A load of weight \(W = 2.0 \text{N}\) is suspended from the spring, as shown in Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[331, 161, 665, 691]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 702, 534, 720]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 733, 181, 752]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 733, 662, 752]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 1.2, measure the stretched length \(l\) of the spring.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[583, 763, 920, 781]]<|/det|>
<form>l = .................................................... cm [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 794, 181, 812]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 794, 767, 812]]<|/det|>
Calculate the extension \(e\) of the spring for a load of weight \(W = 2.0 \text{N}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 810, 433, 829]]<|/det|>
Use the equation \(e = (l - l_0)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[578, 840, 920, 858]]<|/det|>
<form>e = .................................................... cm [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 509, 89]]<|/det|>
The 2.0 N load is removed from the spring.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
A load U is made of modelling clay wrapped on a wire hanger. Load U is suspended from the spring.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 149, 648, 167]]<|/det|>
The student measures the stretched length \(l_{\mathrm{U}}\) of the spring.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[571, 176, 771, 196]]<|/det|>
<form>l_{\mathrm{U}} = .................................................. 7.4

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[853, 178, 920, 196]]<|/det|>
<form>cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 211, 588, 229]]<|/det|>
Calculate the extension \(e_{\mathrm{U}}\) of the spring with load U.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[566, 241, 920, 259]]<|/det|>
<form>e_{\mathrm{U}} = .......................................................... $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 272, 761, 291]]<|/det|>
The extension of a spring is directly proportional to the weight of the load.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 304, 920, 338]]<|/det|>
Use your values of \(W\) and \(e\) from **(b)(ii)** and your value of \(e_{\mathrm{U}}\) to determine the weight \(W_{\mathrm{U}}\) of load U.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 336, 322, 352]]<|/det|>
Show your working.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[561, 446, 920, 465]]<|/det|>
<form>W_{\mathrm{U}} = ..........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 462, 920, 481]]<|/det|>

<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 492, 710, 510]]<|/det|>
Load U is fully immersed in a beaker of water, as shown in Fig. 1.3.

<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 908, 534, 926]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[567, 102, 918, 122]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 693, 152]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[561, 163, 920, 182]]<|/det|>
<form>e<sub>W</sub> = .................................................... $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 194, 526, 213]]<|/det|>
Calculate the density \(\rho\) of the modelling clay.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 210, 702, 229]]<|/det|>
Use your values of \(e_{\mathrm{U}}\) from **(c)**, your value of \(e_{\mathrm{W}}\) and the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[331, 234, 667, 266]]<|/det|>
\[\rho = \frac{\mathrm{e}_{\mathrm{U}}}{(\mathrm{e}_{\mathrm{U}} - \mathrm{e}_{\mathrm{W}})}\times k\mathrm{~,~where~}k = 1.0\mathrm{g / cm}^{3}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[576, 333, 920, 352]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\rho =\) .................................................... \(\text{g / cm}^3\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 350, 920, 368]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 380, 144, 400]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 380, 850, 400]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A student determines the electromotive force (e.m.f.) and resistance of a cell by using a resistance wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 117, 433, 135]]<|/det|>
She uses the circuit shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[168, 144, 829, 495]]<|/det|>

<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 540, 146, 558]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 540, 920, 574]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 2.1, draw a voltmeter connected to measure the potential difference (p.d.) across terminals P and Q. [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 586, 146, 604]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 586, 920, 619]]<|/det|>
The switch is closed. The student moves the crocodile clip on the resistance wire so that the potential difference \(V\) across terminals P and Q is 5.0V.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 632, 658, 650]]<|/det|>
She measures the current \(I\) for the cell and resistor in series.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[324, 658, 670, 826]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 870, 781, 889]]<|/det|>
Read, and record in Table 2.1, the value of \(I\) shown on the meter in Fig. 2.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 870, 920, 889]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

Her readings are shown in Table 2.1. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 114, 541, 131]]<|/det|> Table 2.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[351, 139, 645, 304]]<|/det|>

Start both axes at the origin (0,0). <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 344, 776, 836]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 839, 920, 857]]<|/det|> [4] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 868, 146, 887]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 868, 680, 887]]<|/det|> The e.m.f. \(E\) of the cell is equal to the value of \(V\) when \(I = 0.0 \text{A}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 897, 494, 915]]<|/det|> Determine the value of \(E\) from the graph. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[576, 924, 920, 942]]<|/det|>
E = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[579, 289, 920, 308]]<|/det|>

<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 667, 89]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the refraction of light by a transparent block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 87, 918, 120]]<|/det|>
He uses his results to determine a quantity known as the refractive index of the material of the block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 134, 596, 152]]<|/det|>
The student's ray-trace sheet is shown full size in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 686, 920, 704]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[834, 692, 920, 710]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 903, 89]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the factors affecting the deflection of a wooden strip clamped at one end.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment which enables him to investigate how **one** factor affects the distance \(D\) that the free end of the wooden strip moves downwards when loads are placed on it.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 150, 398, 166]]<|/det|>
The apparatus available includes:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 180, 727, 197]]<|/det|>
a variety of wooden strips which can be clamped as shown in Fig. 4.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 196, 410, 212]]<|/det|>
a set of masses with a hanger.
